Motivation

‚Ä¢ Recent advances in natural language generation

   ‚Ä¢ Powerful language models with high-quality output text (like GPT-*)

‚Ä¢ Concern about using the models for malicious purpose
   ‚Ä¢ Spreading neural-generated fake news / misinformation

‚Ä¢ Language watermarking as a better mark and trace the provenance of text

‚Ä¢ Rule-based language watermarking

    ‚Ä¢ No previous work with language model

‚Ä¢ Neural text detection

Experiment Setup


‚Ä¢ Dataset
    ‚Ä¢ WikiText-2 (Wikipedia)

    ‚Ä¢ 2 million words in the training set
‚Ä¢ Implementation

    ‚Ä¢ Dimension size = 512
    ‚Ä¢ Transformer blocks: 3 identical layers, 4 attention heads









                                                                                               29

Evaluation Methods


1. Effectiveness Evaluation
    By evaluating text utility & message bit accuracy

2. Secrecy Evaluation
    By training watermark classifier

3. Robustness Evaluation

    By performing 3 attacks:
       Random word replace

       Random word removing
       Denoising autoencoder

4. Human Evaluation

Conclusion

‚Ä¢ New framework for language watermarking as a solution towards marking and

  tracing the provenance of machine-generated text
‚Ä¢ First end-to-end data hiding solution for natural text.

‚Ä¢ Discriminator as an adversary improved the watermark system.

‚Ä¢ Fine-tuning with additional language losses improved the output text quality.
